Corynebacterium minutissimum is a species of Gram-positive, non-spore-forming, aerobic bacteria that belongs to the Corynebacterium genus. It is a small, coccoid or rod-shaped bacterium, typically measuring around 0.3-0.8 μm in diameter and 0.5-2.0 μm in length.

C. minutissimum is considered a commensal organism, commonly found on the skin of humans and other mammals. It is part of the normal skin microbiota and typically does not cause disease in healthy individuals. However, in some cases, it can be an opportunistic pathogen and has been associated with a skin condition known as erythrasma, which is a superficial skin infection characterized by reddish-brown, scaly patches.

The bacterium is catalase-positive and can ferment a variety of carbohydrates, including glucose, maltose, and sucrose. It is generally non-hemolytic and does not produce any exotoxins or other virulence factors that contribute to pathogenicity.

C. minutissimum is often identified through microbiological culture techniques, as well as molecular methods such as 16S rRNA gene sequencing. It can be differentiated from other Corynebacterium species based on its small size, biochemical characteristics, and susceptibility to various antimicrobial agents.

Understanding the biology and ecology of C. minutissimum is important for clinical diagnosis and management of associated skin conditions, as well as for providing insights into the role of commensal bacteria in human health and disease.
